Award.AwardTitle: Non-Heme Iron(II)-Nitrosyl and -Nitroxyl Complexes: Key Intermediates in Nitric Oxide Reductases
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Nicolai Lehnert from the University of Michigan to prepare model complexes for the mono- and dinuclear non-heme iron centers in the active sites of bacterial nitric oxide reductases (NORs), and to investigate the mechanistic role that corresponding nitrosyl (NO) and nitroxyl (NO-/HNO) complexes play in the mechanisms of these enzymes. Advanced kinetic and spectroscopic methods, including resonance Raman and magnetic circular dichroism, are to be employed. NORs are found in both denitrifying and pathogenic bacteria, and are thought to play a role in their ability to infect mammalian hosts, as NORs equip these bacteria with resistance to NO, which is a primary immune defense agent in mammals. In addition, non-heme iron enzymes may be involved in the generation and sensing of nitroxyl in biological systems via formation of Fe(II)-NO/HNO intermediates, but the properties of these species are not well understood. Dr. Lehnert and his team will set out to determine the geometric and electronic structures of these species and investigate their biologically relevant reactivity.

Nitric oxide (NO) is biosynthesized in mammals as a signaling molecule, and as an immune defense agent (by macrophages) to fight off invading pathogens. However, certain bacteria have evolved enzymes called nitric oxide reductases (NORs), which efficiently detoxify NO by reduction to non toxic nitrous oxide (N2O) and water. Hence, NORs are thought to promote infection of the human body, leading to chronic diseases. Despite this importance of NORs for bacterial pathogenesis, the fundamental mechanism of NO reduction by these enzymes is not well understood. The proposed studies seek to elucidate the mechanisms of these enzymes. This pursuit will allow graduate students and undergraduates to acquire specialized training in advanced synthetic and spectroscopic methods and computational chemistry. Plans are put forward to include an outreach program to introduce high school students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines to hands-on research in the fundamental sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several gases released into the atmosphere by the activities of human civilization have been identified as green house gases that contribute to global warming. This includes carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (laughing gas, N2O). Nitrous oxide originates from the over-fertilization of the soil in agriculture using ammonia and inorganic nitrates. Denitrifying bacteria and fungi that live anaerobically in soil and sea water transform the nitrates into nitrous oxide in a large-scale process called dissimilatory denitrification, an anaerobic form of respiration. Nitric oxide reductases (NORs) are the key enzymes responsible for the central transformation that generates N2O. In bacteria, this process is mediated by the enzyme NorBC, which has an interesting active site that features two iron centers. Our mechanistic investigations on these enzymes therefore contribute to the currently ongoing, large efforts to better understand N2O generation resulting from denitrification, and what the impact of this process is for global warming.

 

Another important contribution of this project to society relates to the importance of bacterial NO reductases in medicine. The human immune system employs a number of strategies to combat pathogenic infection, one being the release of nitric oxide (NO) at micromolar concentrations, which is very efficient in killing invading organisms. However, a number of pathogens have the ability to detoxify NO by reduction to N2O, using, in particular, flavodiiron nitric oxide reductases (FNORs). These enzymes are therefore capable of promoting pathogenic infection of the human body, leading to chronic infections and inflammations. The work conducted in my group provides insight into the mechanism of these important enzymes by using chemical model systems that allow us to study different mechanistic alternatives for this reaction, obtain chemical insight into the mechanism, and identify important intermediates of the process. For this purpose, we have designed diiron complexes that model the active site of FNORs. While decades of research have focused on the interaction of NO with hemoglobin/myoglobin, much less is known about the binding and redox transformations of nitric oxide with non-heme iron centers. This project has already elucidated key elements of the mechanism of FNORs. In particular, our work has shown that non-heme iron-nitroxyl complexes are likely key intermediates of the process. Using specially designed model complexes, we have determined the properties of non-heme iron-nitroxyl complexes, and we have studied different reactions that these species can mediate. By investigating the catalytic mechanism of FNORs, our work makes important contributions to the greater effort of finding new cures against bacterial infections, in particular drug-resistant strains.

 

Finally, HNO has proven to be a useful therapeutic that protects against tissue damage originating from reperfusion after ischemia (often due to stroke or myocardial infarction). In addition, evidence is accumulating that HNO is also a signaling molecule in mammals. However, it is not known to this date how HNO is produced in vivo and what the targets for HNO-based signaling are. Importantly, our work shows that non-heme iron centers could be sites for HNO production and detection in vivo, and in this way, my group contributes to the great current effort to gain a better understanding of the potential roles of HNO in biology, which has direct implications for human health.

 

Besides these scientific aspects, the new outreach program with Cass Technical High School in Detroit that I started in Summer 2014 (UM Detroit Research Internship Summer Experience, D-RISE) has made important contributions to increase underrepresented minority representation in the sciences by motivating the participating students to attend college and to work in STEM areas. D-RISE provides 7 weeks full-time summer internships to high school students from Cass Tech in the UM Chemistry Department. The most important hallmark of this program is that the high school students do not just observe their graduate student and/or post­doctoral mentors in the laboratory, but the high school students perform full-time hands-on research for 40 hours per week on projects that are directly related to their mentors’ work. In this way, the participating high school students obtain a real research experience. This program was started in Summer 2014 and so far, twelve students have participated. Of the eight students who participated in Summer 2014 and 2015, seven applied to UM for admission to the undergraduate program, all of them were admitted, and five are now pursuing undergraduate studies at UM (the remaining three students now attend Harvard, Stanford, and Wayne State University). Working with high school students provides further, valuable mentoring opportunities to the participating graduate students.
